item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Samuel Beckett
item.description: "ESTRAGON: Do you think God sees me? VLADIMIR: You must close your eyes. Estragon closes his eyes, staggers worse. ESTRAGON: (stopping, brandishing his fists, at the top of his voice.) God have pity on me! VLADIMIR: (vexed). And me? ESTRAGON: On me! On me! Pity! On me!" -- Samuel Beckett

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Kazuo Ishiguro
item.description: "There was surely nothing to indicate at the time that such evidently small incidents would render whole dreams forever irredeemable." -- Kazuo Ishiguro

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Virginia Woolf
item.description: "Her soliloquy crystallized itself into little fragmentary phrases emerging suddenly from the turbulence of her thought, particularly when she had to exert herself in any way, either to move, to count money, or to choose a turning. "To know the truth--to accept without bitterness"-- those, perhaps, were the most articulate of her utterances, for no one could have made head or tail of the queer gibberish murmured in front of the statue of Francis, Duke of Bedford..." -- Virginia Woolf

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Soren Kierkegaard
item.description: "I see it all perfectly; there are two possible situations — one can either do this or that. My honest opinion and my friendly advice is this: do it or do not do it — you will regret both." -- Soren Kierkegaard

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by David Foster Wallace
item.description: "[T]he horrific struggle to establish a human self results in a self whose humanity is inseparable from that horrific struggle. That our endless and impossible journey toward home is in fact our home. … [E]nvision us approaching and pounding on this door, increasingly hard, pounding and pounding, not just wanting admission but needing it; we don’t know what it is but we can feel it, this total desperation to enter, pounding and ramming and kicking. That, finally, the door opens…and it opens outward — we’ve been inside what we wanted all along. Das ist komisch." -- David Foster Wallace

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Søren Kierkegaard
item.description: "People understand me so poorly that they don't even understand my complaint about them not understanding me." -- Søren Kierkegaard

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Franz Kafka
item.description: "Art flies around truth, but with the definite intention of not getting burnt. Its capacity lies in finding in the dark void a place where the beam of light can be intensely caught, without this having been perceptible before." -- Franz Kafka

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Søren Kierkegaard
item.description: "How did I get into the world? Why was I not asked about it and why was I not informed of the rules and regulations but just thrust into the ranks as if I had been bought by a peddling shanghaier of human beings? How did I get involved in this big enterprise called actuality? Why should I be involved? Isn't it a matter of choice? And if I am compelled to be involved, where is the manager—I have something to say about this. Is there no manager? To whom shall I make my complaint?" -- Søren Kierkegaard

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Nathaniel Hawthorne
item.description: "You are partly crazy, and partly imbecile; a ruin, a failure, as almost everybody is,--though some in less degree, or less perceptibly, than their fellows." -- Nathaniel Hawthorne

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Søren Kierkegaard
item.description: "The self is a relation which relates itself to its own self, or it is that in the relation that the relation relates itself to its own self; the self is not the relation but that the relation relates itself to its own self." -- Søren Kierkegaard

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Glenn Gould
item.description: "I believe that the justification of art is the internal combustion it ignites in the hearts of men and not its shallow, externalized, public manifestations. The purpose of art is not the release of a momentary ejection of adrenaline but is, rather, the gradual, lifelong construction of a state of wonder and serenity." -- Glenn Gould

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Søren Kierkegaard
item.description: "Since my earliest childhood a barb of sorrow has lodged in my heart. As long as it stays I am ironic — if it is pulled out I shall die." -- Søren Kierkegaard

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Samuel Beckett
item.description: "I love order. It's my dream. A world where all would be silent and still, and each thing in its last place, under the last dust." -- Samuel Beckett

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Soren Kierkegaard
item.description: "The present state of the world and the whole of life is diseased. If I were a doctor and were asked for my advice, I should reply, 'Create silence'." -- Soren Kierkegaard

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by James Joyce
item.description: "The intellectual imagination! With me all or not at all. NON SERVIAM!" -- James Joyce

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Søren Kierkegaard
item.description: "Intelligence has got the upper hand to such an extent that it transforms the real task into an unreal trick and reality into a play." -- Søren Kierkegaard

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Franz Kafka
item.description: "There is an infinite amount of hope in the universe ... but not for us." -- Franz Kafka

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Søren Kierkegaard
item.description: "As the ironist does not have the new within his power, it might be asked how he destroys the old, and to this it must be answered: he destroys the given actuality by the given actuality itself." -- Søren Kierkegaard

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Bill Watterson
item.description: "God put me on earth to accomplish certain things. Right now, I’m so far behind, I’ll never die." -- Bill Watterson

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by T.S. Eliot
item.description: "the communication/of the dead is tongued with fire beyond/the language of the living"--The Little Gidding" -- T.S. Eliot

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by T.S. Eliot
item.description: "Genuine poetry can communicate before it is understood." -- T.S. Eliot

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Soren Kieregaaard
item.description: "The more one suffers, the more, I believe, has one a sense for the comic. It is only by the deepest suffering that one acquires true authority in the use of the comic, an authority which by one word transforms as by magic the reasonable creature one calls man into a caricature." -- Soren Kieregaaard

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Albert Camus
item.description: "At the heart of all beauty lies something inhuman." -- Albert Camus

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by T.S. Eliot
item.description:
"I sat upon the shore Fishing, with the arid plain behind me Shall I at least set my lands in order?
London Bridge is falling down falling down falling down
Poi s'ascose nel foco che gli affina Quando fiam ceu chelidon—O swallow swallow" -- T.S. Eliot

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Albert Camus
item.description: "But in the end one needs more courage to live than to kill himself." -- Albert Camus

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "The person, be it gentleman or lady, who has not pleasure in a good novel, must be intolerably stupid." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Bill Watterson
item.description: "Hobbes: Do you think there's a God? Calvin: Well, somebody's out to get me!" -- Bill Watterson

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Life seems but a quick succession of busy nothings." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Bill Watterson
item.description: "I'm not dumb. I just have a command of thoroughly useless information." -- Bill Watterson

item.title: Lorraine add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "A woman, especially if she have the misfortune of knowing anything, should conceal it as well as she can." -- Jane Austen
